Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Developing novel methods for estimating coevolutionary processes using tapeworms and their shark and ray hosts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Parasites are everywhere and many species have been with their hosts for a long evolutionary time and are extremely particular about the kinds of hosts they parasitize. Somewhat unexpectedly, recent research suggests that many parasite species do not necessarily share a similar evolutionary history with their hosts; rather other factors may be at play in shaping these parasitic associations. Yet, little is understood about which other factors, such as diet or geographic distribution, influence these relationships. This is largely because a method for assessing the importance of other factors is not currently available. This research will develop a method and will test it using a well-known and species-rich system consisted of the tapeworms of sharks and stingrays. This method will be widely applicable to other coevolutionary systems, helping to further our understanding not only of host-parasite systems in general, but also of other biological systems involving intimate associations. Close species associations are ubiquitous and better knowledge on the role of the environment in shaping species associations will be critical to forecasting biodiversity's response to climate change. The research will train postdoctoral researchers and graduate students in quantitative techniques in evolutionary biology.


This project moves towards a more mechanistic modeling of the biological influences involved in the coevolution between parasites and hosts. Phylogenies will be generated for a large number of cestode genera, time-calibrated phylogenies will be generated for their corresponding shark and ray (elasmobranch) hosts and robust parasite-host association data will be compiled. New methods and open-source software tools using approximate Bayesian computation will be developed to allow the estimation and testing of models for the evolution of parasite-host systems. The models for parasite evolution will be geographically explicit and will include factors such as cospeciation, environmentally driven extinction, geographic constraints on dispersal and host-switching, and some effects of intermediate hosts. These rich empirical data sets will allow the use of robust, cross-validation methods for hypothesis testing. The end result will be a methodological framework for assessing the contributions of multiple factors, in addition to cophylogeny, in structuring host associations and parasite evolution. The new software will be used to address three main research questions regarding factors that underlie parasite-host interactions including the relative roles various factors play in systems with different properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to develop a methodological framework for exploring the contributions of multiple biological and environmental factors, in addition to cophylogeny, in structuring parasite-host associations. Software designed to implement this framework was initially informed by simulated data, and then refined using newly generated empirical data, including robust phylogenies, geographic distributions, and host associations, for multiple groups of tapeworms and their shark and stingray (i.e., elasmobranch) hosts.

New tapeworm material was collected from elasmobranchs in 5 countries to supplement material already in hand and to provide field experiences for student trainees. Sequence data for a portion of the 28S rDNA gene were generated for 500 tapeworm specimens to assist with identifying unique species and to confirm instances of relaxed host specificity (i.e., the same tapeworm species parasitizing more than 1 species of host). To generate robust tapeworm phylogenetic trees for software design, we identified additional phylogenetically-informative genes using newly generated draft genome assemblies and annotations for 15 divergent tapeworm species. These genomes, ranging in size from 274 to 1,745 megabases and in number of genes from 9,535 to 53,726, were used to identify 402 candidate genes across tapeworms. These genes were used as reference sequences for hybrid enrichment and sequencing of hundreds of tapeworm species with varying degrees of host specificity. Eight groups of tapeworms were selected to serve as empirical datasets to inform software design. Efforts to refine sequence data for the 116 species of tapeworms in our 8 target groups focused on 11 of these 402 genes that appear to be phylogenetically-informative.

To generate a robust phylogeny for elasmobranchs, sequence data for the NADH2 gene were generated for 2,158 elasmobranchs to help identify exemplar specimens representing unique species spanning elasmobranch diversity. Sequence data were then generated for 9 additional genes (i.e., MYCBP2, COI, FAT1, VPS18, RAG1, RP2, FZD4, EXTL3, and DISP1) for the 502 species identified. Fossil evidence was compiled and used to inform a Maximum Likelihood analysis of these sequence data to generate a robust, dated, elasmobranch phylogenetic tree. A matrix with tapeworm-elasmobranch associations and geographic distributions was assembled for the target groups.

A new software pipeline that uses machine learning to distinguish between geographical and phylogenetic effects on host-parasite dynamics was developed. Initially we focused on Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC) via simulating from competing models and calculating summary statistics from the simulations. The best model for a dataset would be selected by comparing summary statistics to simulated distributions of statistics. Developing summary statistics that discriminate between similar models was challenging. Summary statistics reported to work well in other applications performed poorly in discriminating between models in which the cause of phylogenetic similarity was the result of biogeography versus those resulting from coevolution. A variety of alternatives were explored using simulated studies. The software pipeline is modular so the software is extensible and will support continued development of new summary statistics. Different groups of tapeworms and hosts may require different summary statistics for the most powerful analyses. The new pipeline (currently called inphest) includes a simulation engine for geographically explicit coevolutionary models, a modular statistic calculator, and scripts for formatting data for input into the pipeline. By default, the simulation pipeline feeds into the ABC inference engine, but we have designed a data model to connect the output to neural-network platforms. The workshop on our software, planned for the 2020 Meeting of the American Society of Parasitologists, was cancelled when the COVID-19 pandemic led to the cancellation of this meeting. We have established a website (http://inphest.org) for disseminating information about the software. We are committed to finishing the migration of information from GitHub repositories to our new website and to completing the implementation and benchmarking of the neural network forms of the inphest pipeline. Phylogenetic trees for hosts and parasites are key inputs to inphest, but species delimitation can be difficult for closely related lineages. In collaboration with another NSF-funded award, we developed a new method and open source software tool, delineate, for estimating which closely related lineages should be considered separate species rather than simply separate populations.

Over the course of the project, 1 post-doctoral scholar, 8 graduate and 7 undergraduate students received training. Results were disseminated via 7 book chapters, 14 journal articles, and 23 presentations at regional, national, and international meetings. A robust elasmobranch phylogenetic tree will serve as a valuable resource for those interested in elasmobranch classification and evolution. The 402 genes of potential phylogenetic utility and the 15 draft tapeworm genomes have the potential to serve as valuable resources for work on flatworm groups beyond elasmobranch tapeworms, many of which are of major medical importance. Code written for the new software has been shared publicly on GitHub. This software will be widely applicable, helping to further our understanding of host-parasite systems and other biological systems involving intimate associations.
